We ordered cheap(er) wine, much to her apparent dissapointment, and mispronounced a few menu items, which totally threw us in the customer trash bin. Finally, and most importantly, they added a mandatory 18% gratuity to our bill, even though the party was only of 5, and there was NO iteration of the condition on the menu.

Don't waste your time. The Olive Garden is classier.
author: Meghana D.

description:
Amarena......A M A Z I N G !  It doesn't get any better than this!   

Every time we eat here we have a great experience! My little brother especially loves the calamari and my dad loves the Seafood Linguini. I really like the Chocolate Salami. (yummy)  

Service: Nicole was very sweet, attentive, and friendly. The food was excellent and reasonably priced. The owner even stopped by to say ciao! 

Great for family occasions and nights out with friends. One of my FAVORITE places to eat. Thanks Amarena!
author: Callie S.

description: My boyfriend and I have been meaning to try this place for a while now.  We finally made it in one evening without a reservation.  They were able to seat us even though they were technically full for the evening.  I was really impressed with the butternut squash ravioli.  WOW!  The sauce was so delicious!  The sangria was tasty too.  I'm looking forward to going back and trying more of the menu.
author: R. B.

description:
Terrific local find. Any local knows that the best Italian in the city is not in the Wharf (or even NB), but can be found in small gems like Amarena. I have eaten here numerous times and have had a great experience every time. I can't recommend a specific dish, but I can say that everything I have ever had was delicious and that I will continue to come back. Great service as well.

Note: Great place to take visiting family!
author: Peter C.

description:
Begin Gordon Ramsey-esque rant:

Don't waste your money or time.  The high ratings surprise me.  Much better can be had in the neighborhood for similar price range.  I know because I live a few blocks away and that is the only reason I have bothered (and regretted it) twice.  I won't be going back.  Both times I found the service to be extremely slow, the food mediocre and overpriced for the quality, and the overall experience a bit disappointing.  This is one of those places that tries to have the image and price of a high end gourmet restaurant but simply does not measure up.  The signs you see places on the sidewalk even a few blocks away trying to lure you in with free wine and appetizer specials should be a dad giveaway that the food and service alone here are not pulling in clientele. 

Regarding the service, it's not the servers' fault at all as far as I can tell, just the fact that there has been only one server and one busser on both times.  TO THE OWNER-SACK UP AND GET MORE STAFF ON, DON'T BE A CHEAPSKATE BECAUSE YOUR PRICES JUSTIFY YOU SPENDING ENOUGH FOR DECENT STAFF, IT'S NEGATIVELY AFFECTING THE DINING EXPERIENCE.   We waited 20 minutes for our drink orders to be taken or to receive any bread etc.  That's a lot of time sitting around with nothing to drink or snack on.  

I ordered the Linguine with seafood and could never recommend it to anyone.  All the seafood in my dish was far overcooked and was very tough.  It felt like I was gnawing though dry old rubber bands.  Half of the dish's size would be attributed to the bulky clam/mussel  shells, many of which were empty.  Some may think this adds authentic appeal or flavor, but really it's just inconvenient, is a way to make the dish look bigger and more elaborate, and if the contents of the shellfish are so poorly cooked it's just a constant reminder of that while you pick pieces of shell out of your dish and mouth.  For $15+ I would expect better.  

Other entrees and appetizers have been slightly better but also failed to impress, especially at the price point.  The house wine was not very good.  Others were satisfactory because I knew what I was ordering ahead of time.  

In a similar price range, it simply cannot compare to superior restaurants like Trattoria Contadina (always excellent) and Frescati, both of which are not far and are outstanding.

Sorry Amarena, but you just need to step it up.
author: Uuri K.

description:
Our first time there, the special happy hr. menu was ok, but the wines and service was EXCELLENT!! we had our baby and todler with us and there very friendly and accommodating.
We also order fried calamari of the menu... very very good!!.
We will be back for sure!
author: Andrea F.

description:
My Amarena experience started off okay. I stopped in here with my husband for a quick glass of wine. It wasn't too crowded and since we weren't eating a full dinner, we took a seat at the bar. There was a huge bowl of sangria on the top of the bar and it looked good, so I ordered a glass. My husband ordered a glass of red wine. Here's where it went down hill... 

The Sangria was too sour and the fruit in it did not seem fresh at all. My husband's glass of wine seemed equally as bad. We spoke to the staff about the wine and of the servers tasted it and said 'oh, it's okay' - anyway, she proceeded to give him another glass of wine (which was also not good). We paid our bill without drinking even an ounce of our drinks & left no tip. We have both worked as servers so this is a big deal for us - we have never not left a tip. We will not be back.
author: Heidi B.

description:
Truly a neighborhood gem. I'm torn between writing a review and keeping it a secret so that I don't have to wait hours for dinner. However, I believe in giving credit where it is due so I can't be selfish about it.  

It's a low carb day for me so I had to forgo the freshly made pasta dishes. Tonight, I had the red snapper special which was perfectly cooked so it was tender and flakey.

The service is attentive but not suffocating, warm and wonderful. The owner is there most nights helping out and greeting guests. He also personally purchases the seafood to ensure freshness. The kitchen staff makes the pasta fresh in-house for the entrees. 

I live in the area so I walk to dinner here. If you are driving, it's Russian Hill so it can be very difficult to find street parking, especially on weekend nights. There are meters on Polk and a couple of garages within a mile or so but if you can avoid driving, your sanity will be saved!
author: S C.

description: After being rejected from Leopold's down the street because it was over 1.5 wait, we decided to try this neighborhood Italian place. The server convinced to get the oso boco which was quite delicious. The place is a big cramped but decent ambience. Wines were decently priced. I ordered a montepulciano for about $30 which was nice.
author: Paul I.

description:
I can't believe how long it took me to try this neighborhood gem. And that's exactly what it is, a gem. I made a reservation for a Friday night, was greeted by a lovely Italian host and seated promptly while he took our jackets to hang up. Our waitress was also very authentically Itallian which just added to the overall experience and charm of the place. Very cozy feeling from the start. 

We ordered a bottle of Primotivo, which was very affordable and delicious! For starters I ordered the arrugala salad with Pear and Pecorino cheese and my friend oredered the special soup of the day which was a roasted tomato. Both delicious. MMMM i am remembering how good that salad is even now. yum!

For mains I ordered the spaghetti bolognese (but swapped out the spaghetti for penne - personal preference) and my friend ordered the butternut squash ravioli. First I loved their meatballs, perfectly seasoned and perfect bite sized balls instead of the huge ones you sometimes get elsewhere. My friend loved the ravioli as well and said it was very rich. 

We passed on coffee and dessert since we were more than a little full. But even as we were walking out the smell of the fresh coffee being brewed almost made us turn around. Maybe next time! And there will be a next time for sure!
author: Lindsay A.

description: We love this restaurant!!! We discovered it through a friend, who we organized a small birthday dinner party with and were impressed by the delicious food, extensive wine list, friendly service and romantic but down to earth atmosphere. Order the pizzoccheri buckwheat pasta with fontina cheese - yummmmmm - Recommended!
author: C. L.

description:
The positives: the atmosphere and the friendly Italian hostess.

The (big) negative: the food. To describe it as mediocre is giving it more credit than it deserves. I have lived in the neighborhood for a while now and decided it was time to give this place a shot- my roommate and I ordered the meatballs as a starter and the gnocchi con funghi e gorgonzola to go. If we had eaten in the restaurant, we would have sent everything back. 

The meatballs were reminiscent of the swedish version in a Stouffer's frozen dinner - bland, tiny, and six to a plate for $10. It seems they tried to make up for the lack of flavor by dousing them in sauce (it was more like find-the-meatball soup); unfortunately, the sauce looked like, and didn't taste much better than, ketchup. Or generic tomato sauce right out of the can. Completely uninteresting.

The gnocchi were undercooked and had the texture of cookie dough, the gorgonzola sauce plain, bland, uninspired. And the funghi were TWO regular white mushrooms. Such a disappointment!

The only thing we liked was the bread, which was obviously home made. 

Completely unsatisfied, we redeemed the meal by ordering from another neighborhood restaurant of reliable quality (see review on Frascati).

I will never return to Amarena, and I suggest you don't either. There are too many great - even too many decent - italian restaurants in San Francisco to waste time and money in a place like this.
author: Miranda B.

description:
Found Amarena by accident when looking for an italian restaurant  yesterday night (we were parked right in front of it and didn't know)... 

Loved the decoration because it made us feel like we were having dinner in a cute italian street.. The hostess and waiter provided a very good service always on top of things!

Food: I could probably go 20 times more to eat their Insalata di Arucola con Pere e Pecorino- Loved it!

The rest of the food was very good, we had the frittura mista, seafood pasta and salmon dish which was outstanding!
author: Angelica V.

description:
I recently came to Amarena for a friends birthday dinner and had a great first experience! We had made a reservation ahead of time, but unfortunately were kept waiting at the front for a little while because the party before us was taking FOREVER to leave. The restaurant owner kindly offered us some champagne (free!) as we waited. This was such a kind gesture, especially on my friends birthday. We toasted and the wait went by in a flash. 

They have a pretty good Italian wine selection and I was impressed with their Truffle pasta (I love anything with truffle sauce!). I also tried the Gorgonzola pasta which was awesome. It was a little difficult to get the attention of our waitress at times, but that may just have been because she was very busy. Overall we had a fun time, ate some great food and enjoyed the nice atmosphere. Id definitely recommend checking this place out!
author: Katie S.

description:
I went here a week ago for a birthday party and wasn't left amazed at all. We ordered basically 4 of each appetizer and everything was just OK. Could be a lot better. The carpachio was just DRENCHED in oil, to the point that my stomach hurt like an hour later and I felt like I drank a gallon of Olive Oil. The friend calamari and shrimp were good but Ive had alot better and at an Italian Restaurant. My favorite dish was the Arugala and Pear Salad. That was probably the only thing that wasn't drenched in oil out of the calamari. For my main course I had their special which was the Filet Mignon in mushroom sauce. That was pretty good I will give it to them. I asked for my Filet Mignon to be cooked medium and it was perfect. Also their tirimisu was AMAZING. I make very good tirimisu but this one was to die for. 
Their service was decent. They didnt have a table big enough to for our whole party so we had two big table next to eat other and I ordered 2 of each appetizer for each table so 4 total and the woman had a hard time understanding. And the main course took a little too long to come out. 
If you are looking for a good Italian Restaurant in the city, go to Panta Rei in North Beach on Columbus and Stockton. Really good food, good atmosphere and really good service!
author: G O.

description:
Exquisite service, a sheer delight.

I arrived with my dinner companion, who had cordially made a reservation for us to dine. We were seated in the back, and given there was room available, a double-table to provide us with more space and privacy in our intimate dining affair. 

I ordered the zinfandel (good, but not the best I've had), he ordered his staple drink. He ordered Sparkly for us both (read: Pellegrino). Have I mentioned that I love that he drinks sparkling water? I did not push this, it is always at his request. *swoon*

I ordered the gnocchi with spinach and mushrooms - good, but maybe a little more spice would've sufficed (black truffle, for instance?). All around, it was quite good, and the texture of the gnocchi was superb.

He ordered the special - the boar back, I believe. Caught wild in Monterey, as recounted to us by the owner. This story delighted us both. 

The tiramisu was a unique take on a staple Italian dessert, complete with mousse, instead of the usual cake-like display. We both quite liked it.

The owner, as we both presumed, ensured we had a beautiful dining experience, complete with personal care and attention to detail.
author: Sally M.

description:
A good friend and I went to Amarena earlier this week, and all I can say is WOW.  The food was absolutely fantastic.  I had lamb chops, and even though they were slightly over-cooked (i got medium well instead of medium rare), they were still delicious.  My friend-date got a pasta dish (can't recall which one unfortunately), and she and I both thought it was excellent.

I'll def be back.
author: Bryan G.

description: Had an amazing night with friends! Service was top-notch. Wait staff was professional and polite, they made great recommendations and were extremely attentive to details. Food, well, I can't recall anything we didn't like! We started off with Pepate de Cozze e Vongole: mussels and clams with a nicely spicy white whine sauce, and affettati misti: charcuterie plate with salted doughnuts ( kind of). We then got Linguini with seafood, bucatini amatriciana and fettuccine with mushrooms. Believe me, that was the best pasta I have ever tried in my life! We ate sooooo much! I'm so happy we tried this place, we will definitely be back soon. The place is cozy and quite small. We went on Monday night and it was crowded, I guess that on weekends it gets crazy, but guys, if you have to wait, believe me, it's freaking worth it!!!!
author: Ashley S.

description:
I had dinner with my friend Saturday night. We had an amazing experience. First of all  I am Italian - I hardly go out to eat Italian food since I can cook it at home plus it's difficult to find an authentic Italian restaurant in the city....when eating italian out I often get disappointed. But not here. I was pleasantly surprised. I felt home, I felt in Italy :) 

The staff is very friendly and the atmosphere is cozy. We didn't have a reservation, therefore when we arrived we had to wait 10-15 minutes for our table, so we decided to order a bottle of Barolo from the bar - which then it was transferred to our table...very good wine from Piedmont! 

To have a taste of different dishes my friend and I decided to share everything. 
We started with the "Burrata" and the "Gnocco fritto con Affettati": the burrata was super fresh and creamy, simply delicious! I wanted my friend to try the affettati: mortadella, prosciutto di Parma, speck and soppressata...like in Italy! She really liked them. 

For the pasta dish the waiter suggested the "Pappardelle al Cinghiale" and the "Ravioli di Zucca": what a great suggestion! I loved the pappardelle: made from scratch by the chef with a super tasty boar meat, mushroom and tomato...they melt in my mouth. A must dish! The ravioli were homemade too and were filled with butternut squash with ricotta cheese.

We were full but we could not leave without ordering dessert: the "Budino caldo al cioccolato" and the "salame al cioccolato"....yeah, both my friend and I love chocolate!  I found the salame al cioccolato being too dry but I loved the budino! It was a great combination of suffle' with vanilla gelato :)

My friend and i had a great experience at Amarena. I can't wait to bring my family and friends at  Amarena and experience again an authentic italian dinner :)
author: Erika C.

description: Great food, delicious pasta, but the service could have been better. Waiting 15 minutes for 2 glasses of wine was sort of a put-off. But it got better as the night went on. Overall, pleased. I'd recommend checking it out.
author: Andrew T.

description:
I have been going to Amarena for 7 years and it continues to be my favorite "Italy away from Italy". Hands down the best Italian restaurant in San Francisco. The food is delicious, authentic italian recipes passed on from generation to generation. The service is always friendly and attentive, and the cozy ambiance makes you want to come back. 

I had dinner at Amarena last night again. This time I tried the Alaskan Cod with tomato sauce, a great meal for a cold night like last night!
author: Elena P.

description:
After walking past its red doors for years, I finally made a reservation at Amarena looking for a nice, quiet place to have dinner, which is exactly what I found.  

We ate there on a Tuesday night and were one of 3 tables with 2 couples sitting at the bar.  It was one of those situations where the crowd was small enough, and the staff friendly enough, that soon it was as if we were all just one big group of old friends.

The physical atmosphere was cozy without being overly so.  

Food was actually the best part.  I had a mildly spicy heirloom cucumber and tomato salad to start (which I thought was inventive) followed by the roasted salmon.  All washed down with pinot noir from a small but well priced wine list.

Don't hesitate for a moment trying out this neighborhood joint (but if you drive, make sure you think about where to ditch your car in advance).
author: David A.

description:
In the overall scheme of things: I would think of this restaurant as an awkward, middle school crush that you fondly remember.  The place still has braces and glasses on but has potential.  This awkwardness mainly had to do with our server (very sweet, and tried hard, but seemingly new to the business - e.g. didn't understand how to course the sides with the mains, instead brought it out with the apps; also, this is not the snappiest service in the world so if you're on a schedule...you've been forewarned).

As for the food: the crush has grown up and now has straight teeth and contacts.  We ordered bruschetta and the spicy cucumber/tomato/basil/red onion salad for appetizers and both were delightfully delicious.  Nothing too pretentious - just good food.  The table bread is dense and warm and buttery too (same bread is used for the bruschetta).

For mains we got spaghetti and meatballs and vegetarian pesto lasagna.  The spaghetti was soooooo good (yes, that many O's are appropriate).  The meatballs were not your typical meatballs - they were more like pan fried meat cakes which sound odd but were a cool change up from the normal simmered for 10 hours in sauce meatballs.  The pasta was fresh and firm and the sauce was full of tomato and basil-y goodness.  As for the lasagna - it was rich, tasty, and very pine nutty.  We also ordered spinach with pine nuts on the side...I want more.  It was garlicky, delicate, not over sauteed, and well accented by the pine nuts.

Desserts: creme brulee - fine, but they topped it off with liqueur.  That made me frown.  Vanilla gelato with cherries - fine too.
author: Priscilla T.

description:
This is a little hidden gem.

The owner is a doll - always treating us to bubbles and special wine whenever we are here. He's so friendly and love his stories.
So of course - I LOVE the staff here!!

Have had almost everything on the menu here - and LOVE this place.
Some of my favorite
1.LineCapesante Scottate
 - yummy scallops
2.LinePolpettine di Carne
- delish meatballs ( great for dipping with bread)
3. Pennette allo Scoglio ( my fave )
- not fishy, really tasty combo - makes my mouth water just thinking about it.
4.Pappardelle al Cinghiale
-2nd fave of mine. Everything is so tasty, u can taste the sweet meat, and tomatoes. YUM
5.Ravioli di Zucca
-Great Veggie option. YUMMY

They have great bands, and HH here on Thursdays! Great date place too! Can't wait to come baack soon :)
author: ThuZ W.

description: The food here is absolutely outstanding. The ingredients are fresh, the portions are right-sized (not huge, not mini), and the service is friendly and attentive. Went here last night and ordered sangria to drink, and had the butternut squash ravioli, gorgonzola gnocchi, and the spaghetti. All dishes were delicious and everyone in our party was pleased. Would highly recommend this spot for great Italian.
author: Erin W.

description: I should have known when I booked the resi this place was 4 stars on Yelp, and the day of our reservation it had already gone down to 3.5. The food was terrible. I wish I never spent $210 at this place (for only 2 people and a special prix fixe menu). The staff was nice. What ruined the ambiance was the fact that there was a tow truck right in front of the only windows in the building shining a bright yellow flashing light directly into the restaurant the whole time, and no one did anything about it. My boyfriend had to get up himself, walk outside, and ask the gentleman to turn it off. Mind you...this was all during our "romantic" Valentine's day dinner. Did I mention that my food came out stone cold...twice? Some romance... I will not be returning to this restaurant.
author: Camille R.

description: I had the best home made ravioli I have EVER had this evening. It was so good that my friend and I (she had the chicken, which was also wonderful) got another order to go... What a truly special SF/ neighborhood gem - the food was very special. Thank you for a marvelous and delicious evening.
author: Melinda E.

description: Had a great experience.  The service was right on for a very busy night.  Soup was very outstanding and our main courses were perfect.  This is a must, but make early reservations. We ate at 7 pm. By 8 there was a line out the door.
author: Rex o.

description:
I wish Amarena was better since I literally live one block away.  I came here once when I first moved to Russian Hill 2 years ago. It was bustling and lively, and overall we had a great time.  But the food wasn't memorable, and the restaurant always looked dead inside whenever I walked by.  

Came back last weekend with some girlfriends on a Sunday night.  We were 1 of 3 tables in the entire restaurant, and yet the service managed to be poor.  Our waitress was not friendly in the least.  She seemed annoyed when we brought out a bottle of wine (despite still making money on the  $20 corkage fee) and then offered us dessert when she already had the check in hand.  The busboy who didn't speak English was nicer than she was.

All said, the butternut squash ravioli is good, despite the tiny portion size. But if you are looking for a solid, reasonably priced neighborhood restaurant with great food and fab service, head up the street to Frascati instead.
author: Joyce W.

description: Small, intimate setting. Warm atmosphere. I've been twice, each time with 4-6 people. I've had the chicken and my girlfriend had the pasta. We both agree the food was terrific. It's a great neighborhood dinner spot.
author: Michael C.

description:
The restaurant has gone down in recent years. The banquette seating was full of stains and quite honestly I was embarissed to have my girlfriend sit down at this place.

Bruschetta was very bland, no garlic or taste of decent quality olive oil.
I am an advocate for small businesses but not when I waste $150 on a bad dinner 

The place was more or less empty - Should I have taken that as a heads up?

Sadly I will not be back.
author: Michael M.

description: Amarena is a restaurant that fits into the Nob Hill dining culture; small, personable restaurants that know how to take care of customers. Restaurants in this area seem to have a lot more love and attentiveness and that clearly shines here from service to food. the food is strictly Italian, full of items that are classics like bruschetta, fritto misto, osso bucco and pastas. All of which were cooked with great ingredients and well done. Throw in a bottle of wine and you are set for a great meal. Surprisingly, this is also good for large groups.
author: Ed L.

description:
I've been here a couple of times and the food is always great.  I really can't find any faults in any of the food. So props to Chef Davide. I especially enjoyed the salume cioccolato and gnocchi with walnut sauce. 

But the main reason I really like it here is the charming owner Paolo and his wonderful staff.  They are very warm and inviting and make everyone feel at home.
author: Roger H.

description:
I had made reservations here about a month ago to bring my special girl.  We have been here on several occasions and do like the atmosphere and food.  Well, this reservation was for Valentines Day and it was a disaster.  First, the normal menu was suspended of which we were not notified about before we arrived at the restaurant even though the restaurant had our information.  Second, when we arrived, they gave us a list of what they would be serving.  A choice of steak or fish.  I don't have a problem with this, but my girlfriend doesn't eat red meat and is not a fan of Sea Bass.  Therefore, the waiter said she could have Eggplant parmesan instead which is vegetarian.  We had the meal in the courses they laid out.  We had no choice about what we would receive in the different courses since we had no choice and the restaurant gave us what they wanted.  For an appetizer, I received raw tuna.  I don't eat raw fish.  This was a waist.  This went on and on and I was very disappointed, but didn't want to ruin the date.  When we were finished, and it came time for the check, it showed that each meal was $85 plus the wine bill.  This meant our bill was for $247 plus tip for 2 people.  Well, this just isn't right since our bill at this restaurant has never been over $80 for both of us total.  We both work for a living and this kind of surprise was not welcome.  Also, the main courses were not even hot.  I don't know how you serve a steak cooked medium that isn't hot at all, unless everything was prepared way in advance.  My girlfriend said the Eggplant Parmisana was just barely warm - and there were only 3 slices of eggplant.  We were shocked.  I tried not to ruin the evening, but when we were brought the check, my girlfriend was brought a very long stemmed rose.  I apparently had a look of shock on my face and she asked why.  I finally told her how much they charged us for the meal, and we both were completely disgusted.  The food was not that good, the service was slow and the waiter even forgot our bread.  Slightly warm food and we were still hungry.  We didn't want to cause a scene, so I paid and we left.  About 1 hour later, since we were still hungry, we went to Subway for something more substantial.  

I will not ever go to this restaurant again since they didn't tell us how much the meal would be prior to the dinner, and then the food was not good at all.  I used to love Amarena, but now, after last night, it is absolute crap and they cheated us and the other couples out of hard earned money.  VERY BAD MANAGEMENT.
author: Jack T.

description:
This place has awful service, is extremely over priced, serves unbelievably small portions, and serves horrible food! Not a good combination. 

The butternut squash ravioli tasted like they were microwaved out of a frozen bag and the filling was so sweet you could barely eat it. My fiance was served salmon so overcooked that it was inedible. I literally wouldn't have fed it to a cat. I had some really dry and tasteless pork tenderloin that came with 3 tiny pieces of thinly sliced pork, 3 tiny potatoes, and a few cherry tomatoes. 

All of the portions were almost criminally small. Also the wine list was outrageously overpriced. They had a bottle of Italian wine for $45 dollars on the menu that I have seen at Trade Joe's for $3.99...dead serious. 

Please do yourself a favor and do not go here.  Go down the street to Frascati for an amazing meal at the same price.
author: Dan L.

description:
People My name is Vino Lino and I am an italian wine Specialist in the San Francisco Area, I must say if you want to enjoy Italia...its food, its culture and a fantastic dining experience then you must come to Amarena! The owner and his staff make you feel like you are in a home having dinner during a fun festive party.  

When you walk into a restaurant and you smell ingredients rather than food you know you are in for a great experience.  The wine is the highlight of the evening.  We had unbelievable wine called Rocca Di MonteMassi, it was a super tuscan blend that knocked our socks off.  The owner Paolo suggested a wonderful dish of Milanese  One of the best pairings I had in a dining experience.  Now here comes the best part, the bill does not match the Food!!!  A very pleasant surprise that does not hit you in the pocket book, overall it is one of the best dining experiences we have had.  

I would highly recommend visiting this Ristorante and asking the servers and or owner to bring you what they think is best!

Vino-Lino
author: Lino V.

description: Great ambiance, but food is very average- we ordered the ravioli and lasagna
author: Romita J.

description:
I really wanted to love this place, because it's in my neighborhood and they have a special on Tuesdays for locals -- 50% off pasta dishes. No such luck.

I'll give them 1 star for having a cozy, romantic ambiance wih the red doors and terracotta walls. I'll give them a 2nd star for having excellent service. We received a friendly greeting when we arrived and the waitress was bubbly (but in a good way) throughout the meal.

Unfortunately, the food was meh. We ordered the bruscetta appetizer, and it was nothing special. Compared to the bruscetta we had last week at Restaurante Milano, the flavors were one-dimensional and the bread seemed less fresh. I ordered the pasta with seafood (sorry, I can't remember the Italian name, and it's not on their online menu any more.) The tomato sauce was tasty, but the pasta reminded me of the stuff I cook at home out of a box. The dish also was skimpy on the fish -- calamari, a couple prawns, and about a half dozen off-tasting mussels. My husband was not impressed with the osso buco either. 

In the end, there are too many great Italian restaurants in this city to warrant a return trip to Amarena.
author: Jennifer Y.

description: Amazing Italian food, fantastic atmosphere and friendly staff.  Last night was my fourth visit and I will definitely be back.
author: T S.

description:
I was assigned to work in San Francisco for two weeks so I flew out two of my teenage nieces (16 & 17) to stay with me at the Fairmont Hotel on Nob Hill since they've never been to San Francisco before. On July 4th, I wanted to take them somewhere nice to eat after the fireworks show.  We drove around and came upon Amarena by accident because it was really hard to find any place that was still opened after 10pm and on a holiday! It was the first decent place that we saw driving around.  

We were greeted by a very lovely hostess in this intimate and warm restaurant where you can tell the food is home-made. My nieces had their fettuccini and fell in love with it. The cream sauce was very good and tasted fresh.  My favorite had to be their creme brulee, which tasted as if it just came out of the oven and melted in my mouth. The girls loved the food here and appreciated the warm service. The meal was reasonably priced. The only reason why I didn't rate this 5-stars is because as good as the food was here for my niece... I cannot honestly say it's my favorite as the menu was limited but definitely different/unique. My favorite italian restaurant is somewhere by Napa Valley, but I cannot remember the name of that place. Once I do... I will definitely write a review on it.
author: Linh N.

description: Came here for a work dinner. The menu was fixed but the food was delicious. However they took forever to bring out the dessert - there was maybe an hour gap! Overall the food was pretty good, and service was very attentive on a Tues night.
author: Leily P.

description:
My fiance and I took my parents here for my mom's bday.  I love the charming atmosphere, red strings of Christmas lights out front during the holidays, and super great service.  

The beef carpaccio is great. 

I loved the gnocci.  (Although, not the best I've ever had.  Try Firenze By Night)

One of my favs in Russian Hill.
author: Lauren S.

description: Food and sangria were delicious!!! Good service. Only silly thing is they make you pronounce the name of the dish properly in Italian when you order. Definitely will be back.
author: Cassandra S.

description:
Awesome food with interesting dishes.
The butternut squash ravioli was DELICIOUS! and so was the chocolate souffle with vanilla ice cream.
author: francesca s.

description: I love Italian food! Some days I'll feel spontaneous and want to eat out at a high-traffic spot, but that also means the chances of getting a table is close to zero. Amarena is a place I always keep in my back-pocket. And it never disappoints!
author: Steven M.

description:
A true neighborhood gem.
Aside from the much appreciated and always fun Thursday happy hours this is the place to feel the southern European vibes. Driven by italian to the bone owner Paolo the place offers a cozy ambiance, great authentic food,excellent selection of wines and a lovely staff.
author: Philip V.

description:
I wish I didn't have to give Amarena two stars, but I thought the food was dull and my pasta was over-the-top  al dente, really tough actually.  
My companions liked their dishes (lamb, veal).  We all ordered dessert, though the offerings were uninspiring and sadly, the Sangria was just meh. 
The place was hopping on a Saturday night, so the noise level was pretty high.  Even though the place was very busy, the service was great.   To be honest, I'm not very excited about going back, but I would probably give it one more try.
author: Karli S.

description:
I went here for a girls outing & had such a great experience. It's a cozy little neighborhood spot that is just so fun & adorable. Since it was a few days before thanksgiving, the chef actually made the beef carpacio (which was outstanding) into the shape of a "turkey" for us. Too cute....the fresh Parmesan cheese shavings were the tail...to help you get the picture! 

Aside from our appetizer...the main dishes were all hearty and flavorful. They also have a great selection of Italian wines. 

This would be a really cute "date night" spot as well. I am happy to have wandered into Amarena on that cold night in November, the ambiance itself warmed me to the soul :)
author: Genie M.

description: Awkward service.  Mediocre food.  Great ceilings and ambience.  Good location.  Hey they have a coat rack.
author: Anon A.

description: I went back to Amarana on a Thursday night and they have a FREE happy hour buffet. The pasta dishes rotate and at some point they bring out muscles. The Malbec is a perfect combo with the buffet. It does take a long time to get service if you have a table outside, but I was ok just going to the bar for more drinks.
author: Mahta P.

description:
Mmmm...another great food happy hour. As in, free food. With the purchase of one drink (wish they had more than one beer, but won't complain abotu free things).

Everything they set out was delicious, and there was a wide variety of things too; several pastas with delicious sauces, a good variety of focaccias, an excellent risotto, even the salad was good. Dessert would have been amazing, but won't complain about free stuff.

The best part is that the bartender marketed it as "all you can eat", not "complementary appetizers".
author: Mark A.

description:
This restaurant definitely deserves more than the 3 1/2 its at right now. I had the butternut squash ravioli and am absolutely in LOVE with it. I would definitely go back for it as a breakfast, lunch, dinner and dessert entree. Their Italian accented waitress was very sweet and helped us get out on time for our play. We also got the lamb. It was a little on the fatty side. But the ravioli gets a hands down 5 star. 
Ciao.
author: Kathleen T.

description: After my last so-so experience with Amarena I wasn't sure if I wanted to go back. They totally redeemed themselves! My family really wanted to go here, so 12 of us walked down and were seated right away at a long table. Everyone loved their food, the service was great, and the price was reasonable. My favorite is still the lasagna cause it tastes so homemade. The beef carpaccio was delicious too. The house wine was fine and the price was right. Overall, Amarena is a great go to for Italian in Russian Hill.
author: Natalie N.

description:
First of all, anyone who claims this place is pretentious is complete off their rocker. The staff is incredibly friendly and attentive! We always have a great experience in this cozy Italian restaurant. The atmosphere is one of the best in the city, yet it still has that friendly neighborhood charm.

As for the food, it's very good! We especially like the pappardelle with wild boar meat -- very rich and delicious. The bruschetta is very nice too, and the bread is phenomenal. All the pasta is homemade and delicious. We've also had the chicken suprema several times and it's always fabulous, very moist and drizzled in a unique pine nut sauce.

Beware other reviewers who name-drop nearby restaurants; they might have other motives for their bad reviews. Give Amarena a shot and you will not be disappointed.
author: Andrew T.

description: This restaurant is superior to its pretentious neighbour, Frascati, in every way. Better atmosphere, better wine list, happier service, and most of all better food. I had to send my fish back at Frascati because it was not cooked. At Amarena, the food is ALWAYS AMAZING! Please head to Amarena instead of over priced Frascati.
author: Nicholas H.

description:
Amarena is literally across the street from my apartment. And I'm glad it is. 

I ordered the boar parpadelle and it was delicious! I would definitely come back again. Reasonable prices, good food, nice service, and ambiance. Thumbs up!
author: Han C.

description:
I'll be short and to the point. 

This is a great place to have dinner with friends, family and on even on a first date.
Every dish I've had from the beet salad to the clam pasta and to the fish main course was tasty and a nice portion.

There's a great selection of wine and you'll even find sangria at their Thursday Happy Hour party. All you can eat for free with a purchase of glass of wine or sangria. Wow!!

The staff is very nice and do their best to make you happy. I can't expect them to treat me as if I were their girlfriend now can I? I'm sure everyone else in the restaurant may think their just as important or more. Ha!
author: Grace G.

description: Cozy trattoria with superlative pasta. It's a romantic area on Russian Hill you might stumble across in the fog
author: Dana B.

description: Went back after 10 months and it was absolutely excellent again. Wine list is obviously chosen by a seasoned oenophile. Food excellent. Elanora was very tolerant of the number of times I yelled "belissima!" at her. She was the best server ever, actually. You've gotta go.
author: D.B. C.

description:
2 Stars

My first time at Amarena. I orders the Arugula salad $8.00 very small. Main course I had the Roasted Wild Salmon $24.00 it wasn't bad. The Salmon was fresh and tasty. However, it came with the skin still on it. I eat out quite a bit and order a lot of salmon this is the first time it came with the skin still on it. Again very small portion. I left still hungry. I did have to ask for bread. The waiter had a bit to much cologne for an eatery. I would not go back.

Pros: Friendly service,

Cons: Very Small portions, tight sitting, no heat in dinning room
author: John L.

description: I really like this place.  First of all, it is incredibly cozy.  It's good for some catch-up time with friends and super cute for a date.  Secondly, the food is delicious.  It is very authentic and very reasonably priced.  The staff and the owner are very friendly - they give an impression of a family atmosphere and create a great go-to neighborhood spot.  Highly recommend checking it out.
author: Osanna A.

description:
No parking so best to take a cab.

We were seated by the window and it was a rainy evening (sets a romantic tone).  

The hostess was really good and very attentive.  She made wine recommendations and they were both (red and white) good.

It has been weeks since we went there, but I do know that whatever we ordered it was delicious so you can't go wrong with whatever you order.
author: R M.

description:
Wow, what else to say but Wow!

Fantastic place for an happy hour especially if the weather is nice, there is a very nice terrace (be sure to arrive early to get it)!

The place is very welcoming, warm atmosphere inside!

The concept is great and simple: buy one drink get free (very good) food. 

I am from Europe and during this happy hour I had there, I was just feeling like I was having a drink in Paris, at the terrace of a little bistro!

The best for you is now to try it! You may see me there by the way!!
author: Alexandre D.

description:
Firstly let me say the food in Amarena is delicious Italian and the service is good but they have some major flaws of small portions and an overpriced wine list.

They run a very good value Early Bird offer which is reduced price of food on their normal menu.  The first time I went I ordered the Early Bird and the food was good but the portion sizes were tiny.  I had ordered Spaghetti meatballs which was basically one large meatball and a tiny portion of spaghetti.  Even if they had added more spaghetti which for them would be cheap it would have made it seem a bit better.

As I liked the food I went back and the next time I asked the waiter if the portion sizes on their normal menu are bigger than the early bird offer and was was told they were and ordered off the normal menu.  The portion size was still small.  I don't know why they are sacrificing customers by providing insufficient quantity of food.  

The wine list is ridiculously overpriced for a casual Italian and it is cheap quality wine with a big markup.  If someone wants to go out for a nice casual meal it is nice to have a good value bottle of wine available to go with it.
author: Claire m.

description:
I'm in SF for the first time ever, and starving from a long day of sightseeing.  We are driving around the Nob Hill area and have no clue what to eat or where to go.  So what do we do?  We go on Yelp of course!  We see a few restaurants and decide on Amarena.  Best decision of our day!!  This place was AMAZING!  To start with, the place was packed, we didn't think we had any chance of getting a table.  The extremely helpful host, worked his magic, called a reservation who hasn't shown, and then moved a few tables around to find us a spot.  How great is that?!?  This place is very authentic, our waitress was literally FROM Northern Italy, and had a great accent.  

On to the food, my favorite part.  Our server was quick, helpful, fun, and made sure we had a great time.  We started with her recommendation, a bottle of red wine and the  Caprese salad, which was possibly our second best decision of the day.  The mozzarella literally pulled apart when you put your fork into it, as if it had been made just moments before served.  The mozzarella was by far the best I have ever had, and I am a cheese addict.  If you go here, and don't order the Caprese salad, you are a fool.  My girlfriend who doesn't even like tomatoes loved it.  As for the entrees, I ordered the spaghetti and meatballs with bolognese sauce and it was definitely one of the best I've had!  The girlfriend got the risotto which was delicious (yes I ate at least a third of it).  Our other friend ordered the special, which was a Pork Tenderloin and that was probably my favorite dish of all.  The bottles of wine we got were perfectly paired with all of our meals, and I really wish we had tried desert.  Next time!

Overall, it was an amazing experience.  Next time I am in SF I will go out of my way to eat at this restaurant.  I have a feeling it isn't nearly as well known as it deserves to be.  Thank you YELP!
author: Daniel A.

description: I love this spot. I am RIDICULOUSLY close to it, so I am glad the service and food is so good. The specials tend to be way better than what's on the regular menu. Listen to the servers on their wine recommendations!
author: Katrina H.

description:
I really wanted to like this place since it is about a block away from my house and if I am anything, it's lazy. Walked in and received a warm greeting at by the host. That was nice. The experience went downhill from there. I went for Valentine's day for the preset four course meal. (With a date, obviously. Not alone.)The food was nothing special-it was average. Small portions. 

But the service was AWFUL. It was clear that they were trying to get you in and out as quickly as possible. We barely finished one course when the waitress would bring us the next, and she even brought out our desserts out before we had finished out entrees, so we got to sit at this tiny table with both. There was no offer to refill our waters or to bring us more bread. And it wasn't just me who noticed this-the couple sitting next to us made a similar comment after the waitress took their check before they even had a chance to sign it. We finished a four course meal in under an hour and fifteen minutes. 

And I get it-the economy is bad and restaurants are struggling and V-day is a profitable night. But if you are going to charge $75/person for average food, at least provide your patrons with a pleasant dining experience instead of practically forcing them to inhale their meal. I would think that making people want to come back to your restaurant is a better business strategy that having one profitable night and pissing off potential customers. There are plenty of other good Italian restaurants in San Francisco. I will not be coming back.
author: Hope A.

description: Be warned! They do not know how to keep your reservation. Apparently they do this consistently as I read other reviews that had a similar situation. I made a reservation on open table for a party of 6 on a Friday night.  They called me an hour before and asked of they could push from 8:30 to 9. She was pushing it even though I was not happy I said ok. We get there at nine and then she says it will be 10 min. But then 20 min. Later still not seated. I asked the hostess if she could comp us a glass of wine while we wait since it is an hour after our original reservation time and she was rude about the whole thing. We had to find somewhere else to go...would not recommend.
author: Melissa R.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here the other day while visiting San Francisco. We were on a quest to find a small, romantic Italian restaurant near Nob Hill. After reading a couple of reviews, some good, some bad, we decided to check it out anyway. Once we walked in (so exhausted from the long walk up the hill), the hostess greeted us and was extremely friendly. She complimented me on my necklace which didn't hurt. 

We sat by the window and there was only one other table filled, which made me a bit skeptical, but then again we were eating at around 6 (pretty early for people in SF, perhaps?) The waitress was EXTREMELY friendly and was always coming by to make sure we were happy.

I ordered the Baked Tube Pasta with spinach and ricotta cheese. OH MY GOD. It was DELICIOUS. I'm salivating still thinking about it. It came in an adorable home-feel dish, and was baked to perfection. In fact, it was so rich and decadent I could hardly finish it. My boyfriend ordered the Pappardelle al Cinghiale (with boar meat) and he liked it a lot, but ended up liking my dish more. I'm surprised no one has reviewed it yet, but maybe that's because it's a new dish? 

The owner (I think it was the owner?) came over to say hi and was really friendly. Overall, we were very satisfied and would come back again! (Definitely for dessert next time.. this time we were wayyy too full)
author: Jenna F.

description: This neighborhood gem is tucked away in Russian Hill, in a residential area. The butternut squash ravioli and gorgonzola gnocchi were pretty amazing. The bruschetta was very fresh, with really flavorful tomatoes, and the baked zucchini was the perfect sized app for 5 people to share. I'd come back to Amarena with a small group.
author: Kelly N.

description: Went here for a friends birthday, about 8 of us. The service was very friendly, atmosphere semi formal but comfortable, definitely not a stuffy crowd. The food was good, I thought my dish could have had more flavor, but i tried a bite of some friends' dishes and they were much more flavorful. I will try this place again probably with a smaller group.
author: Jen O.

description:
Food:
Pappardelle with the Wild Boar ragu, single best pasta dish in the city! Everything is freshly made and you can tell they take pride in quality of ingredients. The roasted beets salad is delicious, and a great way to start your meal.

Service: 
That's what separates this restaurant from other great establishments, the service is wonderful. Paolo co-owner and front of the house staple, is just such a warm and inviting person. He clearly enjoys what he does and it shows.

Size/Location:
Quaint restaurant that lends itself to any romantic or casual dinner. When the weather is nice they have outside seating available, and on Thursdays there is a live band.

One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.
author: Fernando E.

description: Really disappointing. I've lived in the neighborhood for 5 years and have only eaten here twice. The first time the food was fine and the service was bad. This last time the service was fine and the food was bad. With so many great Italian restaurants in the neighborhood (Pane e Vino, Contadina, all of North Beach), I'd skip this one.
author: J S.

description:
When I'm craving Italian and convenience (i.e. proximity), it's hard to bypass Frascati. But my aunt insisted we that check out a new spot in my hood, and after a little yelping I settled on Amarena. 

Couldn't have been happier with my pick. Fist off: ambiance. Amarena is warm, cozy and perfect for thawing on a cold January night. We had the entire restaurant to ourselves, which I hope was indicative of a typically slow Sunday and not the dwindling economy (eek). 

Impressive wine list too, considering that my aunt - an unofficial connoisseur - found a never-before-tasted varietal: syrae (not syrah). The manager (owner?) came over to chat and share his opinion: apparently syrae is best described as a drier cab. Whatever the label, it was delicious, and we split two bottles between the four of us...and after a full day of wine tasting too. 

Onto the food: we were three for three with the appetizers. Two crispy wedges of polenta were coated in a rich, creamy gorgonzola and mushroom sauce. The eggplant parmesan was stacked three layers high with parmesan and herbs wedged between each layer of perfectly cooked, non-mushy eggplant (a crucial element, according to my fellow diners). And the golden beet salad with ricotta dressing was light, fresh, and flavorful. 

Because winter calls for comfort food, we all indulged in Amarena's homemade pasta dishes. The Veal Shank was so tender that the meat literally fell off the bone in the Osso Buco, and the seafood linguine was piled high with salmon, clams, calamari, and prawns. The butternut squash ravioli in a brown butter sauce was ridiculously fresh and light - not your typical coma inducing pasta dish. Amarena really hammers home the difference between homemade pasta and the store bought variety.   

Ended on a sweet note with a warm chocolate sufflè and a dollop of vanilla ice cream. Perfection.
author: A M.

description:
It would be 3-3.5 stars overall BUT the food was good so I decided to give them 4 stars.

Have always wanted to try this place.  I love that they have red lights stringed around the outside and the tree - looks cozy and romantic.  On Halloween night, we were able to find parking nearby and they were near empty.  There were only 2 other tables when we walked in so we can pick our spot.  Unfortunately, all of their tables are TINY and they are packed so close to one another.  I'm not a big person but I was not comfortable at the table, it just felt so tight and the surface didn't have enough space for anything.  

Besides the close quarter feel, we do like the ambience.  The restroom is in the back just behind curtain with a note on the door advising you to please knock before entering because the lock is broken!

What we had:
A glass of Montepulciano and Primitivo - $8.50 each
Tuna tartare - special of the day - $13 - big chunks, good portion - fresh and tasty
Tagliolini Ossobuco - $19 - delicious!  One large bone in ossobuco placed upright in the middle of the plate with homemade tagliolini in creamy porcini mushroom sauce.  Hubby was eyeing my ossobuco and I was kind enough to share it.
Pappardelle Cinghiale - $16 - pretty good.  Homemade pappardelle with wild boar ragu.  

Service was lacking and a large party that was pretty loud came in so we decided to skip dessert than tolerate the noise.
author: Gloria H.

description: 3.5 if yelp would let me. It's a quaint, romantic and intimate solid Italian restaurant. The service was good; charming Italian waitress. I will definitely go back again. The reason for withholding the extra star is that, while good, it didn't blow me off my feet.
author: Anna J.

description:
I've lived in the neighborhood for 4+ years now and don't know why i've never been to Amarena. As it turns out, i've been missing out! Cute and cozy place, with great food that is not overpriced. 

Some of the other reviews have complained about "small" portions, but personally I enjoyed being able to fnish an entree for once and not feel like I had to overstuff myself to get through a meal. 

The daily specials were delicious and fresh. Paolo the owner was also our waiter and very accomodating. The only reason it lost one star, was that we were the only party in there. I know it's not their fault, but I couldn't help but feel bad for the place... 

At any rate, I will definitely be going back - especially for their Thursday live music and happy hour!
author: jaja w.

description:
I dined here last night with three friends and while the food was really good there were some serious problems with the service.  Really friendly staff but we were ignored for long stretches.  A couple of other minor problems-it was really hot inside the restaurant  (people were sweating-eww) and the music went from a nice pleasant level to club level house beats around 9pm.  
I would give Amarena another shot but am not rushing back with so many other great options in the neighborhood.
author: phil h.

description:
I'm not typically a romantic.  I get queasy in sappy movies and avoid love songs like the plague.  But Amarena *sigh* makes me swoon.  The ambiance is intimately cozy with soft lights and old Italian melodies.  The food?  Unbelievable.  I ordered the Salmon, but was informed by Pablo, the charming owner and chef, that he had forgotten to pick up the organic cherry tomatoes.  He asked if I would enjoy a light champagne and grape sauce instead, and of course I said yes.  Now I can't imagine it any other way.  Amazing!
If you go, be sure to try a bottle of the Montepulciano D'Abruzzo and the Caesar Salad.  And the Tiramisu!
Oh, I could go on and on.  But Boyfriend really gets mad points for taking me here.  I'm still swooning.
author: Christine M.

description:
For my 300th review, I racked my brain trying to figure out what to write about. I didn't want to pick any old place and instead wanted somewhere that I loved, but had neglected to review until now. I finally decided Amarena, one of my neighborhood gems.

First I should begin by telling you a little about fella. He's a great cook and prides himself on making excellent Italian food -- which he does. The only problem with that is that he never wants to go to an Italian restaurant when we go out because he feels (somewhat legitimately) that he can make better food at home. I, however, love to go out to eat and like to change up the cuisine choices.... not having Italian on our potential list of food made me sad. Our compromise is Amarena.

What my fella loves most of all when it comes to food is seafood, which fortunately, is where Amarena really shines. Delicious, fresh seafood pastas and appetizers, especially the calamari and the squid ink pasta. The wine list is reasonably priced and the service is always attentive. If you happen to be in the neighborhood on a Thursday, stop in and see if they are having their happy hour (it's only every other Thursday), when they offer live music and free food and drinks.  

Thank goodness for Amarena which single-handedly brought Italian food back into our restaurant rotation.
author: Rebecca H.

description: I've clocked a number of hours at Amarena over the years, and have always been a little puzzled by its "love it or hate it" reputation on Yelp.  Count me among the lovers.  I only order one thing on the menu (which is very unusual for me): fresh papardalle with duck ragout.  Sometimes they'll do it with wild boar instead, which is equally tasty.  Just give it a try -- I all but promise you'll like it.  Order a glass of whatever sangiovese they have on the menu, and you'll be enjoying a really nice, relatively inexpensive meal in a cute spot.
author: Laurence W.

description:
Absolute horror show. 

We had some out-of-town guests and took them to this place because it looked good on Yelp, and cute when walking past. Bad idea. I repeat--bad idea. 

The waiter was utterly totalitarian. We ordered an antipasti and got a bottle of wine, but he refused to let us order the main dishes.. okay...

I was stoked about getting the pappardelle (from what I read on Yelp) but it wasn't on the menu, or the specials! And then, get this, when two from our table of four were ready to order the Osso Bucco, he told us they had just run out--and this was an 8pm Friday reservation. Yikes.

In the end, we got a Linguine di Mare (dry and tasteless), a Ravioli (boring, bland), and two fish dishes, which were unfresh and utterly disgusting. And get this, the recommendations the waiter gave us, which we took, were more expensive than any main dishes on the menu. OMG--can this get any worse...

This place is a nightmare, with bad service, cooking that some three-year old made with rotting fish, and maybe even paid Yelp reviews. 

Not coming here, even if you paid me. And what a huge embarrassment for our out-of-towners.
author: Min L.

description:
It's rare that I walk into a restaurant, have decent food, and still leave there saying it's unlikely I'll return. But hey, that is my Amarena experience.

Three of us arrived at 7pm on a Sunday night and waited for two more friends to join. The waitstaff were pleasant but clearly inexperienced and not terribly enterprising. (A touch of the Basil Fawlty with only 50% of the mania, if you know what I mean) The restaurant was far from crowded, but we had to ask for virtually everything - the bread basket, to place our food order, to open the clearly-meant-to-be-uncorked bottle that we brought with us (corkage is $15). The background music was best described as the bottom-of-the-barrel-automated-restaurant-pipe-through-the-worst-of-the-worst-elevator/airport-muzak. Not quite the environment-builder that we'd hoped for.

Between us, we ordered a couple of salads to start and an entree apiece. My friend ordered the chicken special and was told, at 7.45pm, 25 minutes after we placed the order, that they'd run out . We expressed mild curiosity at this point as to how a special could have run out so early. We're sorry we asked. "Um, it's been a special for about 2 weeks and it was starting to go bad, so we've been really pushing it lately". This was revealed as a 'joke' only after we had all guffawed in horror/concern. Certainly left us wondering.

Anyway, the salads pitched up and were pretty decent - one basic mixed green affair with oranges and fennel, the other  a delish beet salad with some sort of leafy greens, drizzled with a pesto-like dressing. Too bad we had to wait about 40 minutes after the salad being cleared to experience entrees. (and again, bear in mind we were practically the only people there.)

I think our party was generally pleased with the quality of their main courses. I had a squid ink linguine with various seafood items tossed through it, and it was pretty tasty. My roommate, on the other hand, opted for veal scallopine stuffed with proscuitto and some sort of cheese. It was all going fine until he found a couple of chunks of aluminium foil in his entree. We politely called over the owner, Paulo, to comment on this. In return there was neither horror, surprise or apology - all we heard was the equivalent of "ah, that's the way they cook it".  Tough luck for my roomie I guess.

Toward the end of the night, our hapless waiter invited us to happy hour "tomorrow night". We expressed surprise and delight at a happy hour on a Monday when we'd been told that happy hour was actually on Thursdays. Turns out our waiter THOUGHT it was Wednesday. And commented on how quickly the week had gone. I'm sorry, I have an MBA and yet that math eludes me.

To the restaurant's credit, we did end up with some free dessert (two of the party had been at a happy hour the prior Thursday and bonded with the Pro-aluminium foil owner, which probably explains that). But at the end of the day we had a lot of talking points related to our dining experience at Amarena, and not many of them related to the food. 

Basta, as they say in Milano.
author: Leela S.

description: Phenomenal...! This place is a warm friendly environment. Not only is the food exceptional, but the prices are reasonable. It is a great place to take a date for a romantic evening without breaking the bank for Russian Hill dinning standards. Living so close to this fine restaurant has been a treat for my roommate and I. Every other Thursday is Free Tapas for happy hour. Their happy hour lasts till about 9pm. Plenty of food for dinner...  It's a nice break for those young worker bees like me.
author: Dee C.

description:
Two totally different experiences at Amarena that happened within a week of each other. 

The first was delightful - My friend and I came in for dinner and the place was packed. Our server was a cute little Italian guy who felt bad about making us wait to put in our drink order, and he ended up giving us free champagne all night - 3 glasses each! All the food was very reasonably priced. I had the butternut squash ravioli and they were delicious and the total bill came out to $40 for the two of us. My only complaint was that the place was ridiculously loud and not really conducive to conversation.

The second time I came with a large group and the restaurant was practically empty. Everyone's orders came out at the same time... except mine. No explanation from the server. About ten minutes went by and he finally came out with my risotto. It was totally undercooked and inedible. Clearly, they'd forgotten about my order (somewhat understandable since there were about a dozen of us at the table), but what I was really pissed about was that the tried to quickly throw together a dish that takes a long time to cook and can't really be put together in a hurry. The server was nice and brought me a free dessert, but still.. I left with a bad taste in my mouth. (Although, not of risotto.)

So the verdict? With all the other cute little Italian places in my neighborhood, I don't see a reason to come back here.
author: Lindsey S.

description:
Almost hits the 4 star mark, but not close enough. The food was worth 4 stars.  However, the decor and ambiance detracted.  Albeit I ate an early dinner with girlfriends, but at 6pm the dinning room was D-E-A-D.  

By 7pm, there were only 3 other parties in theplace.  

The place was also very, very cool - and I mean that literally.  After I had to put on my winter jacket in order to eat, I asked the waiter if he could turn the heat up a pinch. He told me they don't have heat!!!  How does a place not have a heater at all!?  Ok, and why don't they get a space heater.  it was really uncomfortable to eat feeling that cold.  Me and my friends were so chilly from dinner we got home and sat in front of the heater for 15 minutes.

The vegetarian ravioli was yummy.  the souffle was great, and liquidy in the middle.  mmmmmm. The bread was homemade and delicious.
author: Angie C.

description:
this place definitely has a lovely ambiance... our food was solid, but not memorable.

After reading prior yelp reviews it sounds like gnocchi is their forte, so i'll have to be back to sample before i make anymore deliberations about the food.  I'm also excited to see that they have squid ink pasta on their menu - will definitely try that next time.

Paolo and his staff are very friendly and inviting which makes it a fun place to go when you're feeling chatty.
author: lulu p.

description:
I wish the following review was fake and that my wild imagination came up with the details.  Unfortunately, its all true.  Hang on to your seats.

I stopped in Amarena on my way home from work.  Its the last of the Russian Hill restaurants for me to try and since I was just about to hit my 1 year mark in the 'hood, I thought I'd finish off the list.  

I wish I could speak to the food and the drink.  I remember having risotto that was passable.  Pasta too.  Glass of wine.  But, really, all of that paled in comparison to what was going on at the table next to me - the one against the window.  

The couple ordered wine (I think they were European...Italian, maybe?).  And the next thing I know, I see the woman pull something out of her purse and put it on the table.  It was her DOG!  A little furry thing!  And it proceeded to lick out of her WINE GLASS!  NO LIE!  

don't get me wrong...I LOVE dogs!  But I think its agains the health code to have a dog in a restaurant...and on the white table cloths?  getting its drink on?  ARE YOU SERIOUS?  and the server came back a few times and didn't say a word...like it was the most normal thing ever.

I got my leftovers wrapped up (a "doggy bag"...ha!  get it?) and paid out.  On my way out, I told the manager that I thought it was against code for them to have the dog...and he just smiled and sent me on my merry way.  

Bummer...I really wanted to like this place.
author: Susan L.

description:
This is a great neighborhood spot for dinner. They tend to get a late-dinner crowd. Went there the other night, had the garlic shrimp for a starter and the dungeness crab and scallop ravioli in cream sauce for my meal. Pretty good food and decently priced. The owner stopped by to say hi adding to the neighborhood feel. I liked the feel of the place, not pretentious, but classy. They have a $15 corkage fee, not bad. It's a go-to spot if you're in the mood for Italian, you don't want to pay too much and you don't have a reservation.

They also have a daily happy hour -- free antipasti and drink specials-- from 5-7pm.
author: Defne A.

description:
I do love Amarena. It truly is a neighborhood Italian gem!!!  It's very cute, with the red lighting on the trees outside. Makes me really want to have dinner here on a warm night and sit at one of the sidewalk tables.

The staff is so friendly and fun. The food is really great too.  Although I must admit, I've been three or four times, and I always get the same pasta. But the warm, doughy bread to start with is sooo good, and everything else my friends have ordered has definitely pleased them.

I want to share my most recent experience there with you. We had a dinner party of 10 one night, well it started as ten, but as the dinner went on, a few more of our friends showed up.  By the end of the night there were 15 or 16 of us closing down the restaurant with our beloved waiter, bartender and (I think) owner, singing and toasting to a lovely Saturday evening.
author: Julie B.

description:
This place is pretty amazing, almost as amazing as Ristorante Milano, but in my opinion, Ristorante Milano is the best Italian joint in SF. Either that or Il Borgo in Hayes Valley.  This place is pretty up there though, too.  I've been here a few times and have never been disappointed.  The only time I was disappointed was New Years Eve 2007 as my date was moreso the thing that lacked substance! HA! 

Anyway, I don't know if it's still on the menu, but their Osso Bucco is OUT OF THIS WORLD. So tender. I never though anything would top the Osso Bucco I had at Allred's Restaurant in Telluride, Colorado in 2004 ( i know, my memory rulezzz).  I've also had the salmon, which comes with capers and lemon juice (my favorite)!  All in all, this place fits how I would describe DELICIOUSNESS.
author: Jenny W.

description:
This has definitely become one of my favorite Italian restaurants.  Everything is wonderful, and I love the ambiance and the servers.  We started coming here about six months ago, and have already been back several times.  

Love, love, love Amarena!
author: Meghan L.

description: So darling and so charming. This restaurant epitomizes the quaintness of Russian Hill. Service is wonderfully Italian and the food is superb.  The tomato sauce in the calamari is tangy but sweet and the pappardelle with boar ragu was delicious. I also heard wonderful things about the butternut squash ravioli.
author: Natalie S.

description:
I was all ready to love this place and have it as another great, cozy, ro-man-ti-cal Italian option in my neighborhood.  The menu looked interesting and promising, and upon walking in, I thought the surroundings were nice.  However, it started going downhill from there.

The service was completely awful.  Nobody who worked there seemed to give a shit.  While the gnocchi was a treat, the duck pasta was boring and nothing special, and my tablemate's minestrone was honestly saltier than the Dead Sea.  Another who had been excited to try the squid ink linguine was disappointed by its forgettability.  

But really, though, the terrible service is what made the dining experience an unfortunate waste of time and money.  I'll keep going to Antica Trattoria and Ristorante Milano (or try one of the many others in the area) instead.
author: daphne w.

description:
I've had 2 experiences on Amarena on different nights and both could not have been more different...

My first visit was a Sunday - the service was attentive, the food was outstanding, perfect ambiance and quality wine.  Based on that experience I'd give Amarena a 4 star rating. 

My second visit was on a Thursday evening... oh, how different.  The restaurant is turned into a rowdy wine bar and serving food takes 2nd place.   In the `wine bar` half of the restaurant it is standing room only and incredibly loud.  `Aperitivo'` are served for free.  These consisted of doughy bread and poor quality salads.  

Unfortunately for those paying $100 for a meal for two you're left with poor, unattentive service and food served up cold.    

Amarena should decide what they are... a rowdy bar or a quality restaurant. 

I may try Amarena again, but never again on a Thursday.
author: mark b.

description:
I'm always curious how I'll end up liking a place when the reviews on Yelp are so hot and cold as they are with Amarena. 

I had a late dinner at Amerena last night with my boyfriend, and in the end we came out on the 'hot' side (hence the four stars). The servers were friendly, attentive and charming and, most importantly, the food was AMAZING. I mean it. Really tasty Italian cuisine. 

I had the Spinach Gnocchi and the texture was superb. My boyfriend had the Spaghetti Bolognese and he was equally impressed with the flavor of his dish (he always orders the Spaghetti Bolognese at every Italian restaurant we go to so he is somewhat of a connoisseur).

We had a nice bottle of wine, and an appetizer each, so dinner for the two of us was about $120 including tip. Well worth it.
author: Casey C.

description:
Cozy, warm and inviting with tasty Italian standards, this neighborhood spot is tucked away on the quiet corner of Green and Larkin. Flickering lights adorn the trees outside, beckoning strollers by into the friendly, romantic restaurant. 

The soft, delicious "bottomless basket" of homemade bread is an indication of the attention to detail at Amarena. Pastas are perfectly cooked, sauces are piquant and service is down-to-earth and chatty, if at times a bit distracted.  A recent meal was heartily enjoyed by myself and my charming blue eyed companion - starters were a Caprese salad with heirloom tomatoes, a toothsome beef carpaccio sprinkled with capers and a wonderfully creamy polenta with shitake mushrooms and gorgonzola. Already somewhat sated by the starters, we opted to share the dungeness crab & scallop ravioli as an entree. Bathed in a decadent walnut cream sauce and ringed with marinara - it was superb. Two glasses of chianti rounded it all out quite nicely.

The prices here are a good value compared to some other spots in the vicinity. An early bird option is also available for those times when you want to pull the purse strings a bit tighter. Dine from 5:30 to 6:30 and receive half off entrees.
author: wendella a.

description: Amarena is a gem. I went here for the first time with my mother for a lazy Sunday dinner. The atmosphere is lovely, and our server was great all night. The wine list was extensive, and every dish we had was delicious. The Insalata di Lipari was nice and spicy--a unique take on a simple salad. The Pappardelle al Cinghiale (pasta with boar meat ragu) we intended to get as a starter and take home whatever we didn't finish since we also each got a main meat plate, but ended up practically licking the dish it was so good. The pasta was clearly made in-house, probably the day-of. Our meat dishes were fantastic: the lamb racks were cooked to perfection. The chocolate Budino was the perfect cherry on top of a stellar meal. The only small complaint I had about this place was it was  bit cold--I kept my jacket and scarf on during the whole meal. Would come back here in a second, and recommend it for all intimate and/or special occasions.
author: Mithra H.

description: Loved this place. A quiet, little romantic spot and the food was fantastic. We had the Burrata alla Caprese, the Gnocco Fritto con Affettati (fried dough pieces that you wrap in Italian cured meats) for appetizer- both of which were absurdly good. For dinner we split the Chicken stuffed with cranberries and ricotta in pine nut sauce and a menu special -a tagliatelle pasta with pork and bacon in a rich cream sauce. All of it delicious and perfectly cooked. Also the wine list is pretty good. It's Italian, so come prepared to not be in a rush. The service is a tad on the relaxed side, but if you go for a late dinner, its not as busy. Top that off with a cozy Italian ambience and you've got yourself a lovely evening.
author: Margie C.

description:
I'd have to say, after living across the street from this place for years, seeing it crowded on most nights, it did NOT live up to the hype.  I was actually pretty disappointed.  Went with a friend for dinner on a Thursday night.  NOTE: they only have the "music"/"drink specials" every other Thursday.  We, however, got the off Thursday.  They do have a food happy hour menu so we luckily arrived to get those specials.

The food happy hour menu was pretty good.  We started with the calamari.  It was fine.  Nothing spectacular.   It basically tasted like tempura and they gave us this tomato sauce to dip it in.  We also got the beet salad.  Also, fine.  Nothing to rave about.  Both were well under $10 with the happy hour special.  My meal was also a pretty good deal.  I got a huge gnocchi for $7 and it was on the regular menu for about $15.  The gnocchi I got had sausage and a tomato sauce.  Also fine.  The actual gnocchi was very good.  The sausage and tomato sauce however weren't great.  I think the best part of the meal was the bread.  It was delish.

Well, unfortunately, I probably won't be back.  For Italian food, I'd rather go up the street to Milano. Sorry, Amarena.  Maybe I'll see you at the happy hour but not anywhere else.
author: Rachel S.

description:
Amarena is a little slice of Italy right in the heart of Russian Hill.  It has the feel of a quaint, rustic trattoria with hearty dishes and amazing wines. It's one of the better Italian restaurants in the city  and I'm picky about Italian since I grew up eating the real deal.  Their fresh gnocchi is to die for!  And the waiters aren't too bad either ;)

I would recommend this establishment for a great date night.
author: Lauren T.

description: The bf and I went to this place last night, since we both wanted pasta and didn't want to venture too far from my house. The meal was fantastic! I had a glass of malbec and he a pinot noir, and we both loved our selections. We split a tomato/cucumber salad with balsamic dressing, very refreshing and delicious. He ordered some sort of linguini in a red sauce with bacon in it, which was terrific, but not as good as my dish. I ordered the special: home-made fettucini with bits of prosciutto, shrimp, cherry tomatoes, and clams I think. It had a light white wine sauce, and was seriously, seriously fantastic. The pasta was cooked perfectly al dente, and the flavors were wonderful. It was the perfect amount of food, too, so I didn't hate myself after finishing everything. Reasonable prices, considering the quality. WIll be back!
author: Cat M.

description: This place is very authentic. The owner and servers are actually from Italy and do a great job giving the place a friendly neighborhood warmth. The food is delicious, they do all of the classics just right and mix in some innovative specials. The best part about Amarena is that the owner will often bring the wine to your table, chat and make you feel at home. Prices are very reasonable for the quality of the service - this place is no frills - just simply great food and authentic, friendly service.
author: Alex P.

description:
